words.ENTRY: <H>karaoke</H><audio>karaoke.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>uncountable</bracket><D>a type of entertainment in which a machine plays only the music of popular songs so that people can sing the words themselves</D>

keepverb(past, past participle kept) 1.to continue to have something, permanently or for a period of time: You can keep that pen. I don't need it anymore.Can I keep the car until next week?2.to continue to be in a particular state or position: You need to keep warm.That boy can't keep still.Keep close to me and we won't get separated.

<H>kind</H><audio>kind.mp3</audio><PS>noun</PS><bracket>countable</bracket><D>a group whose members all have the same qualities:</D> <X>The concert attracted people of all kinds.</X><dot><X>The concert attracted all kinds of people.</X><dot><X>Many kinds of plants and animals are being lost every year.</X><dot><X>I'm interested in all different kinds of music.</X>

knowverb(past knew; past participle known) (not in the continuous tenses) 1.to have knowledge or information in your mind: I don't know much about sports.Do you know their telephone number?Did you know that Jon enjoyed painting?2.to have met or seen somebody before: We've known each other for years.3.to be familiar with a place: I don't know this part of the city well.4.to speak or understand a language: I don't know much Spanish.5.to be able to do something: Do you know how to swim?you know (informal) 1.(used when the speaker is thinking of what to say next): Well, you know, it's kind of hard to explain.2.(used when the speaker wants to check whether somebody understands what he/she is saying): It just makes me really mad, you know?
I bought one of those new bread machines, you know, like the one Mike has.
